Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Implementing and Analyzing 3-Dimensional Variants on Digital Neuropsychological Exams
Award.AbstractNarration:
The field of clinical neuropsychology has placed increasing emphasis in early detection of cognitively degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Existing research in digitizing the diagnosis process aims to help specialists bring their services to rural areas where access to neuropsychologists may be limited. This research intends to further explore new kinds of clinical neuropsychology exams designed to enrich collected data for computational analysis. The researcher will create a 3-dimensional variant of the existing popular Trail Making Test in neuropsychology. Existing normative data from paper-and-pencil Trail Making Tests show clear correlations between age and average test completion time among cognitively healthy users. The project will explore whether similar correlations can be found in this proposed variation among a wide distribution of age ranges. This project will be conducted at the University of Tokyo under the mentorship of Dr. Takeo Igarashi, one of the field's leading researchers in 3D computer graphics and Human-Computer Interaction.

The test will be constructed for use in touch-enabled tablet devices, where patients will rotate a sphere comprised of labeled boxes and tap the next correct box in pre-determined sequences. The data points of most interest reside in the sphere manipulation behaviors as well as finger gesture data. Sphere manipulation would be captured by creating an invisible trail placed directly at the center of the screen's viewport. As the sphere rotates, the changing coordinates of the viewport as a function of time are stored, effectively recording where the patient was observing the sphere at any time. These coordinates will then be mapped to a 2D plane as treated as a digitized sketch, allowing machine learning techniques typically used in sketch recognition to be used in this context, with the intent to help classify the user's behavior in sphere manipulation per their cognitive function.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the development and deployment of a novel clinical neuropsychological examination. The 3D Trail-Making Test was developed in Unity and relied on a touch screen to enable the participant to manipulate a sphere made of labeled boxes. Testing active memory, rudimentary depth perception and image recognition among other cognitive functions, the 3D Trail-Making Test was designed for participants of all ages and computing expertise.

 

The test was developed and deployed at the University of Tokyo from June 2017 to August 2017. Additional participants from the United States were recruited in September and October 2017. Data analysis and classification was completed by late October 2017, and efforts to expand participants to include those who may suffer from cognitive impairment is ongoing.

 

The system was tested on a 52 participants, 20 of which were of Japanese nationality and 32 of American nationality. In order to better understand how this test can capture subtle changes in behavior, our user study collected touch input in real time and analyzed participants’ finger movement attributes such as acceleration, speed, directional changes, and movement curvature among others. Using machine learning classification, we were able to distinguish between Japanese and American participants with an accuracy of up to 92%. This suggests enough behavioral data was collected in high enough amounts such that our classifier recognized meaningful user behavioral changes between both populations.

 

This developed software and promising classification results provide a strong foundation to deploying this system onto people suffering from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and similar debilitating conditions, such that we can identify early signs of MCI before a turnover to Alzheimer's or other kinds of dementia. Our immediate work to be completed is to work with practicing clinical neuropsychologists to deploy this system for live patient use, such that we can develop machine learning classification that can distinguish behavioral changes between cognitive states, rather than country of origin.

 

We seek to expand country-of-origin classification following the foundation presented by several existing normative studies of clinical neuropsychology by expanding the amount of American and Japanese participants in the near future, as well as participants from other countries. Analyzing behavioral changes across cultures and nations can yield greater insight into how cognitive function differs among populations. In addition, it may provide valuable normative data to better identify how cognitive impairment manifests across said populations.


Last Modified: 05/31/2018
Modified by: Raniero A Lara-Garduno

The 3D Trail-Making Test was developed in Unity and relied on a touch screen to enable the participant to manipulate a sphere made of labeled boxes. Testing active memory, rudimentary depth perception and image recognition among other cognitive functions, the 3D Trail-Making Test was designed for participants of all ages and computing expertise. The test was developed and deployed at the University of Tokyo from June 2017 to August 2017. Additional participants from the United States were recruited in September and October 2017. Data analysis and classification was completed by late October 2017, and efforts to expand participants to include those who may suffer from cognitive impairment is ongoing. The system was tested on a 52 participants, 20 of which were of Japanese nationality and 32 of American nationality. In order to better understand how this test can capture subtle changes in behavior, our user study collected touch input in real time and analyzed participants? finger movement attributes such as acceleration, speed, directional changes, and movement curvature among others. Using machine learning classification, we were able to distinguish between Japanese and American participants with an accuracy of up to 92%. This suggests enough behavioral data was collected in high enough amounts such that our classifier recognized meaningful user behavioral changes between both populations. This developed software and promising classification results provide a strong foundation to deploying this system onto people suffering from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and similar debilitating conditions, such that we can identify early signs of MCI before a turnover to Alzheimer's or other kinds of dementia. We seek to expand country-of-origin classification following the foundation presented by several existing normative studies of clinical neuropsychology by expanding the amount of American and Japanese participants in the near future, as well as participants from other countries. Analyzing behavioral changes across cultures and nations can yield greater insight into how cognitive function differs among populations.
